quotaConfirm.dangerMessage: You're almost at your monthly limit. This generation will use most of your remaining quota.
quotaConfirm.exceededMessage: You've reached your monthly quota limit. Please upgrade your plan or wait until next month.

header.title: Simple, transparent pricing
header.subtitle: Choose the plan that fits your needs

promotion.title: Early Access: Pro features FREE!
promotion.description: Sign up now and enjoy Pro features at no cost during our launch period

specview.question: What is an AI Spec Document?
specview.answer: An AI Spec Document automatically organizes your test cases into domains, features, and behaviors. It helps you understand your test status at a glance.

analysis.question: What is Analysis?
analysis.answer: Analysis parses your repository's test files and extracts test cases, frameworks, and statistics. It's the foundation for understanding your test suite.

paymentLive.question: When will payments go live?
paymentLive.answer: We're currently in early access. Paid plans will be introduced in the first half of this year. Early users will receive special benefits and advance notice.

retention.question: What is data retention?
retention.answer: Retention period determines how long you can access your dashboard history and generated AI spec documents. Repository analysis results are kept regardless of your plan.

landing.title: Documentation
landing.description: Learn how SpecVital works and get the most out of your test analysis.

testDetection.title: Test Detection
testDetection.description: Understanding how SpecVital finds and counts tests in your repository.

usageBilling.title: Usage & Billing
usageBilling.description: Learn about usage tracking, quotas, and billing cycles.

githubAccess.title: GitHub Access
githubAccess.description: OAuth permissions and GitHub App installation for organization repos.

queueProcessing.title: Queue Processing
queueProcessing.description: How analysis queues work and priority tiers for different plans.

specviewGeneration.title: AI Spec Generation
specviewGeneration.description: How AI transforms your tests into structured specification documents.

meta.title: Usage & Billing | SpecVital Docs
meta.description: Learn about usage tracking, quotas, cache behavior, and billing cycles in SpecVital.

usageBilling.title: Usage & Billing
usageBilling.subtitle: Understanding how usage is tracked and when quotas reset.

whatCounts.title: What Counts as Usage?
whatCounts.description: SpecVital tracks usage for two main features: Analysis runs and AI Spec Document generation. Not all actions count toward your quota.

keyPoint.title: Cached Results Are Free
keyPoint.description: Viewing cached analysis results never counts as usage. You're only charged when new work is performed.

analysisRun.name: Analysis Run
analysisRun.description: Parsing test files from a repository

specDocGeneration.name: AI Spec Doc Generation
specDocGeneration.description: AI generates specification document (counted by test count)

usageTypes.title: Two Types of Usage
usageTypes.description: SpecVital has separate quotas for different features, each tracked independently.

analysis.title: Analysis Runs
analysis.description: Counted each time you analyze a repository. One run per repository, regardless of test count.
analysis.item1: Initial analysis of a new repository
analysis.item2: Reanalysis after new commits or parser updates

specview.title: AI Spec Docs
specview.description: Counted by the number of tests in the generated document. More tests = more usage.
specview.item2: Regenerating uses the new test count

cache.title: Cache Behavior
cache.description: SpecVital caches analysis results to save your quota and speed up access. Understanding when cache is used helps optimize your usage.

sameCommit.name: Same commit, same parser
sameCommit.description: Viewing a repository you already analyzed

newCommit.name: New commits available
newCommit.description: Repository has new commits since last analysis

tip.title: Efficient Usage
tip.description: Cached results are served instantly and never count toward your quota. Only update when you need the latest analysis.

cycle.title: Billing Cycle
cycle.description: Your usage quota resets monthly. The reset date is based on when you first signed up.

howItWorks.title: How Monthly Reset Works
howItWorks.step1Desc: Your billing cycle starts on the day you create your account.
howItWorks.step2Desc: Usage accumulates for 30 days from your start date.
howItWorks.step3Desc: On day 31, your usage counters reset to zero automatically.

limits.title: Plan Limits
limits.description: Each plan has different monthly limits for analysis and AI spec generation.

warnings.title: Quota Warnings
warnings.description: SpecVital warns you before you run out of quota so you can plan accordingly.

approaching.title: Approaching Limit (80%)
approaching.description: When you reach 80% of your quota, you'll see a warning indicator in the UI. Consider upgrading or waiting for reset.

exceeded.title: Quota Exceeded (100%)
exceeded.description: When you hit your limit, you won't be able to perform new analyses or generate spec docs until reset. Existing results remain accessible.

checkUsage.title: Checking Your Usage
checkUsage.description: You can monitor your usage in several places throughout the app.

items.accountPage: Account page shows current usage and limits
items.generateDialog: AI Spec generation dialog shows remaining quota
items.resetDate: Reset date displayed with days remaining

q1.question: Does viewing cached results use my quota?
q1.answer: No. Viewing previously analyzed results is always free. Usage is only counted when new analysis or generation work is performed.

q2.question: What happens when I exceed my quota?
q2.answer: You won't be able to start new analyses or generate new spec documents until your quota resets. All existing results remain accessible, and you can still browse, search, and export.

q3.question: Does regenerating a spec doc count as usage?
q3.answer: Yes. Each generation counts based on the number of tests at that time. If your repository grew from 100 to 150 tests, regenerating will use 150 units.

q4.question: Can I buy more quota mid-cycle?
q4.answer: Currently, quota cannot be purchased separately. You can upgrade your plan for higher limits. We're considering usage-based options for the future.

meta.title: Test Detection | SpecVital Docs
meta.description: Learn how SpecVital detects and counts tests in your repository using AST-based static analysis.

testDetection.title: Test Detection
testDetection.subtitle: Understanding how SpecVital finds and counts tests in your repository.

what.title: What is Test Detection?
what.description: SpecVital uses AST (Abstract Syntax Tree) based static analysis to detect tests in your codebase. Unlike CLI tools that execute tests, SpecVital parses source code directly to identify test functions, suites, and their status.

keyPoint.title: Static Analysis
keyPoint.description: Tests are analyzed without execution. This means results are available in seconds, not hours - no CI/CD setup required.

how.title: How It Works
how.description: SpecVital uses Tree-sitter parsing to analyze source code across 10+ programming languages. Framework detection follows a priority-based approach:

detectionOrder.title: Detection Priority
detectionOrder.step1Desc: Highest reliability. e.g., import '{' test '}' from 'vitest'
detectionOrder.step2Desc: Files within a framework's config scope. e.g., jest.config.js

frameworks.title: Supported Frameworks
frameworks.description: SpecVital supports 20+ testing frameworks across 10+ programming languages:

filePatterns.title: File Patterns
filePatterns.description: Tests are detected based on standard naming conventions for each language:

countDifference.title: Why Counts May Differ from CLI
countDifference.description: SpecVital counts dynamically generated tests (parameterized tests) as 1 test, regardless of actual runtime count. This is because static analysis cannot evaluate runtime values.

tip.title: Accurate Counts with C# Attributes
tip.description: C# attribute-based tests like [TestCase] and [InlineData] are accurately counted because each attribute is individually detected in the AST.

status.title: Test Status Detection
status.description: SpecVital detects test status based on framework-specific modifiers and attributes:

limitations.title: Known Limitations
limitations.description: Due to the nature of static analysis, some patterns cannot be fully detected:

indirect.title: Indirect Imports Not Supported
indirect.description: Files that import test functions via re-export chains may show 0 tests. SpecVital parses each file independently without following import chains.

items.singleFile: Single-file parsing - cannot resolve aliases across files
items.dynamicImports: Dynamic imports and runtime-generated test names
items.macros: External macro-based tests (Rust crates without 'test' in name)

accuracy.title: Accuracy Expectations
accuracy.description: For projects using standard testing patterns, SpecVital achieves high accuracy. Projects with heavy parameterization or custom test infrastructure may see lower accuracy.

typical.title: 95-99% Accuracy
typical.description: Most projects using standard patterns will see highly accurate test counts. For exact counts, use your framework's native CLI (jest --listTests, pytest --collect-only).

q1.question: Why does my test count differ from jest --listTests?
q1.answer: Parameterized tests (it.each, test.each) are counted as 1 test in SpecVital because the number of iterations is only known at runtime. Jest counts each iteration separately.

q2.question: Why are some of my tests showing 0 tests?
q2.answer: This usually happens when tests import test utilities through re-export chains. SpecVital cannot trace imports across multiple files. Try importing directly from the testing framework.

q3.question: How often is the parser updated?
q3.answer: The parser is updated regularly to support new framework versions and patterns. When an update affects your results, you'll see a banner suggesting reanalysis.

meta.title: GitHub Access | SpecVital Docs
meta.description: Learn about OAuth permissions and GitHub App installation for accessing organization repositories.

githubAccess.title: GitHub Access
githubAccess.subtitle: Understanding OAuth permissions and GitHub App installation for repository access.

overview.title: How SpecVital Accesses Your Repositories
overview.description: SpecVital uses two authentication methods to access your GitHub repositories: OAuth for personal accounts and GitHub App for organization repositories. This dual approach ensures secure, granular access control.

keyPoint.title: Read-Only Access
keyPoint.description: SpecVital only reads your source code to analyze tests. We never write to your repositories, create issues, or modify any data.

methods.title: Two Authentication Methods
methods.description: SpecVital uses different methods depending on whether you're accessing personal or organization repositories.

oauth.title: OAuth (Personal Repositories)
oauth.description: Standard GitHub OAuth flow for personal account access. Grants access when you sign in with GitHub.

githubApp.title: GitHub App (Organization Repos)
githubApp.description: Installed by organization admins for secure org-wide access with granular permissions.

scopes.title: OAuth Scopes
scopes.description: When you sign in with GitHub, SpecVital requests the following OAuth scopes:

repoRead.name: repo (read)
repoRead.purpose: Read repository contents to analyze test files

userEmail.name: user:email
userEmail.purpose: Identify your account and send notifications

orgRead.name: read:org
orgRead.purpose: List organizations you belong to (for GitHub App guidance)

comparison.title: OAuth vs GitHub App
comparison.description: Understanding when each authentication method is used:

whyGithubApp.title: Why GitHub App for Organizations?
whyGithubApp.description: GitHub's security model requires organization admins to explicitly approve third-party access. OAuth alone cannot access organization private repositories without admin approval.

adminNote.title: Admin Approval Required
adminNote.description: Organization owners must install the SpecVital GitHub App. Regular members cannot grant organization access via OAuth alone.

security.title: Enhanced Security
security.description: GitHub Apps use short-lived tokens that automatically rotate, reducing security risks compared to long-lived OAuth tokens.

granular.title: Granular Permissions
granular.description: Admins can grant access to specific repositories rather than all-or-nothing organization access.

audit.title: Audit Trail
audit.description: All GitHub App access is logged in the organization's audit log for compliance and security reviews.

installation.title: Installing the GitHub App
installation.description: Organization admins can install the SpecVital GitHub App in a few steps:

selectOrg.title: Select Organization
selectOrg.description: Go to Explore > Organizations tab and click 'Install GitHub App' for your organization.

chooseRepos.title: Choose Repositories
chooseRepos.description: Select 'All repositories' or choose specific repositories to grant access.

authorize.title: Authorize Installation
authorize.description: Review the permissions and click 'Install' to complete the authorization.

complete.title: Start Analyzing
complete.description: Organization repositories will appear in your Explore tab immediately after installation.

permissions.title: Permissions Requested
permissions.description: The GitHub App requests minimal permissions needed for test analysis:

read.label: Contents (Read)
read.description: Read source code files to analyze test patterns and extract test information.

metadata.label: Metadata (Read)
metadata.description: Read repository metadata like name, description, and default branch.

readOnly.title: Strictly Read-Only
readOnly.description: SpecVital never requests write permissions. We cannot modify your code, create branches, or change any repository settings.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.description: Common issues and how to resolve them:

cantSeeOrg.title: Can't see my organization
cantSeeOrg.description: Your organization admin needs to install the GitHub App first. Contact your org admin or request access through GitHub's third-party access settings.

pendingRequest.title: Access request pending
pendingRequest.description: If you requested access and it's pending, your organization admin needs to approve the request. Check your organization's 'Third-party access' settings.

repoNotListed.title: Repository not listed
repoNotListed.description: The GitHub App may be installed with 'Selected repositories' instead of 'All repositories'. Ask your admin to add the repository to the allowed list.

managing.title: Managing Access
managing.description: You can review and revoke SpecVital's access at any time:

items.oauthSettings: Personal OAuth: GitHub Settings > Applications > Authorized OAuth Apps
items.appSettings: Personal App: GitHub Settings > Applications > Installed GitHub Apps
items.orgSettings: Organization App: Organization Settings > Third-party access > GitHub Apps

q1.question: Why can't I see my organization's private repos?
q1.answer: Organization private repositories require the GitHub App to be installed by an organization admin. OAuth alone only grants access to your personal repositories. Ask your admin to install the SpecVital GitHub App.

q2.question: Is my code stored on SpecVital servers?
q2.answer: SpecVital processes your code in real-time and caches only the analysis results (test counts, file structure, etc.). Raw source code is not permanently stored on our servers.

q3.question: Can SpecVital modify my repositories?
q3.answer: No. SpecVital only requests read permissions. We cannot create commits, branches, issues, or modify any repository content.

q4.question: How do I revoke SpecVital's access?
q4.answer: For personal access, go to GitHub Settings > Applications and revoke from there. For organization access, an admin must uninstall the GitHub App from the organization's settings.

meta.title: Queue Processing | SpecVital Docs
meta.description: Learn how analysis queues work and priority tiers for different plans.

queueProcessing.title: Queue Processing
queueProcessing.subtitle: Understanding how analysis queues work and priority tiers for different plans.

overview.title: How Queue Processing Works
overview.description: When you submit a repository for analysis, it enters a processing queue. SpecVital uses a multi-queue architecture to ensure fair processing while providing faster service for premium plans.

keyPoint.title: Fair & Prioritized
keyPoint.description: All jobs are processed fairly within their tier. Premium plans get dedicated queues with shorter wait times and higher concurrency.

architecture.title: Multi-Queue Architecture
architecture.description: SpecVital operates three separate queues to balance fairness and premium benefits.

standard.title: Standard Queue
standard.description: Shared queue for free tier users. Jobs are processed in order of submission.

priority.title: Priority Queue
priority.description: Dedicated queue with faster processing and higher worker allocation.

dedicated.title: Dedicated Queue
dedicated.description: Highest priority with dedicated workers and minimal wait times.

tiers.title: Priority Tiers
tiers.description: Each plan tier has different queue characteristics:

howItWorks.title: Processing Flow
howItWorks.description: Here's what happens when you submit an analysis request:

submit.title: Submit Request
submit.description: You enter a repository URL and click Analyze. The request is received by our API.

route.title: Queue Routing
route.description: Based on your plan tier, the job is routed to the appropriate queue (Standard, Priority, or Dedicated).

process.title: Worker Processing
process.description: A worker picks up your job, clones the repository, and runs the test parser on all detected test files.

complete.title: Results Ready
complete.description: Analysis results are cached and immediately available. You're redirected to the results page.

waitFactors.title: What Affects Wait Time?
waitFactors.description: Several factors influence how long you wait in the queue:

queueLength.title: Queue Length
queueLength.description: More jobs ahead means longer wait. Premium queues typically have fewer jobs.

jobSize.title: Repository Size
jobSize.description: Larger repositories with more test files take longer to process, affecting overall queue throughput.

planTier.title: Your Plan Tier
planTier.description: Higher tiers get dedicated queues with more workers and less competition.

timeOfDay.title: Time of Day
timeOfDay.description: Peak hours (weekday business hours) may have longer queues. Off-peak times are typically faster.

whyPriority.title: Why Priority Queues?
whyPriority.description: Our multi-queue system balances accessibility with premium service:

fairness.title: Fairness for Free Users
fairness.description: Free tier users always have access to analysis. Their queue is processed continuously, ensuring everyone can use the service.

predictability.title: Predictable Performance
predictability.description: Premium users get predictable, fast response times. Important for CI/CD integration and professional workflows.

scalability.title: System Scalability
scalability.description: Separate queues allow us to scale each tier independently based on demand patterns.

status.title: Real-Time Status
status.description: You can track your analysis status in the UI:

queued.label: Queued
queued.description: Your job is waiting in the queue. Position and estimated time are displayed.

processing.label: Processing
processing.description: A worker is actively analyzing your repository.

complete.label: Complete
complete.description: Analysis finished. Results are cached and ready to view.

q1.question: Why is my analysis taking longer than expected?
q1.answer: Wait times depend on current queue load and your repository size. Large repositories with thousands of test files take longer to process. During peak hours, standard queue may experience longer waits.

q2.question: Can I cancel a queued analysis?
q2.answer: Currently, you cannot cancel a queued job. Once submitted, it will be processed. If you need to analyze a different branch, submit a new request.

q3.question: Do cached results skip the queue?
q3.answer: Yes! If your repository was previously analyzed at the same commit, results are served instantly from cache without entering any queue.

q4.question: What happens during system maintenance?
q4.answer: During maintenance windows, queues pause temporarily. Your job remains queued and will be processed when maintenance completes. We announce scheduled maintenance in advance.

meta.title: AI Spec Generation | SpecVital Docs
meta.description: Learn how AI transforms your tests into structured specification documents.

specviewGeneration.title: AI Spec Generation
specviewGeneration.subtitle: Understanding how AI analyzes tests and generates specification documents.

overview.title: What is AI Spec Generation?
overview.description: AI Spec Generation transforms your test cases into human-readable specification documents. By analyzing test names, assertions, and structure, the AI extracts the underlying business requirements and presents them in a clear, organized format.

keyPoint.title: Tests as Living Documentation
keyPoint.description: Your test suite already contains valuable specification information. AI Spec Generation surfaces this knowledge, making it accessible to developers, QA, and stakeholders alike.

pipeline.title: Two-Phase Generation Pipeline
pipeline.description: AI Spec Generation uses a two-phase approach to ensure accuracy and consistency in the generated documents.

phase1.title: Classification Phase
phase1.description: The AI analyzes each test to determine its type and purpose. Tests are categorized into functional, edge case, integration, unit, or performance tests.
phase1.input: Raw test cases with names and assertions

phase2.title: Document Generation Phase
phase2.description: Classified tests are grouped by feature and transformed into structured specification documents with clear descriptions and acceptance criteria.

classification.title: Test Classification
classification.description: The AI classifies tests into the following categories based on their characteristics:

functional.name: Functional
functional.description: Tests that verify core business logic and user-facing features
functional.example: should create user with valid email

edge.name: Edge Case
edge.description: Tests that verify boundary conditions and error handling

integration.name: Integration
integration.description: Tests that verify interactions between multiple components
integration.example: should sync data with external API

unit.name: Unit
unit.description: Tests that verify individual functions or methods in isolation

performance.name: Performance
performance.description: Tests that verify response times and resource usage

howItWorks.title: Generation Process
howItWorks.description: Here's what happens when you generate a spec document:

parse.title: Parse Test Structure
parse.description: The system extracts test names, describe blocks, and assertion patterns from your test files.

classify.title: Classify Tests
classify.description: Each test is analyzed and classified by type (functional, edge case, integration, etc.).

group.title: Group by Feature
group.description: Tests are grouped into logical features based on file structure and describe block hierarchy.

generate.title: Generate Document
generate.description: The AI generates a structured specification document with feature descriptions, acceptance criteria, and test coverage information.

output.title: Output Format
output.description: Generated spec documents include the following elements:

structure.title: Hierarchical Structure
structure.description: Documents are organized by feature areas, making it easy to navigate and understand the system.

context.title: Business Context
context.description: Each feature includes a description explaining its business purpose and user value.

markdown.title: Markdown Format
markdown.description: Documents are generated in Markdown for easy viewing, sharing, and integration with documentation systems.

caching.title: Result Caching
caching.description: Generated documents are cached. Regeneration only occurs when tests change or you explicitly request it.

limitations.title: Known Limitations
limitations.description: While powerful, AI Spec Generation has some limitations to be aware of:

accuracy.title: Classification Accuracy
accuracy.description: Test classification is based on naming patterns and heuristics. Some tests may be miscategorized if they don't follow common conventions.

language.title: Language Support
language.description: Best results with English test names. Tests in other languages may have reduced accuracy in classification and description generation.

context.title: Limited Context
context.description: The AI only sees test code, not implementation. It infers behavior from test names and assertions, not actual functionality.

complexity.title: Complex Tests
complexity.description: Highly complex tests with many nested conditions may produce less accurate or overly simplified descriptions.

bestPractices.title: Best Practices
bestPractices.description: Follow these tips to get the best results from AI Spec Generation:

naming.title: Use Descriptive Test Names
naming.description: Write test names that describe the expected behavior (e.g., 'should return 404 when user not found' rather than 'test404').

structure.title: Organize with Describe Blocks
structure.description: Group related tests under describe blocks that name the feature or component being tested.

coverage.title: Include Edge Cases
coverage.description: Tests for edge cases and error conditions provide valuable specification details about system boundaries.

q1.question: How is usage counted for spec generation?
q1.answer: Spec generation usage is counted by the number of tests processed. Each test in your repository counts toward your monthly quota when generating a new spec document.

q2.question: Can I edit the generated spec document?
q2.answer: Generated documents are read-only in SpecVital, but you can export them as Markdown and edit them in any text editor or documentation system.

q3.question: Why doesn't the spec match my actual implementation?
q3.answer: Spec documents are generated from tests, not implementation code. If there's a mismatch, it may indicate your tests don't fully cover the actual behavior.

q4.question: How often should I regenerate specs?
q4.answer: Regenerate when you make significant changes to your test suite. For active projects, we recommend regenerating after each sprint or major feature completion.
